history.content: Hmmm as someone who also came in to Berkeley with no prior CS experience (currently a declared sophomore), I truly think it comes down to you wanting to learn and putting the time into projects.  I had no idea what frameworks/APIs/etc meant at the beginning of last semester, but after 4 or so hackathons, I kind of started to not only pickup the vernacular but also learn how to work with them.  I'd say take some time this semester/this summer to work on some side projects.  Spend time understanding why you're doing what you're doing.  Whenever I go to a hackathon I mostly just google articles on which framework I want to do, and I think you'll find more resources the further you get into your project(s).  I'd highly recommend learning Ruby on Rails first if you haven't experience with any other frameworks- there's lot's of support, a Codecademy tutorial on Ruby/Rails, and MVC architecture is pretty common in other fields like iOS.  Best of luck!

children.subject:
Also, off the top of my head, here's a list of things that are trending right now: MVC, REST APIs, MEAN stack, LAMP stack (still relevant!), React and Vue.js, Docker (containerization), IoT, responsive design, chatbots, NoSQL, blockchain.

But you don't have to keep up-to-date with all of that. Just focus on stuff you're into. I'm into deep learning so AFAIK the big thing right now in deep learning is the Wasserstein GAN. I couldn't tell you much about it, but that won't stop me from casually name-dropping it in a conversation. :) Truth is, most people you meet don't know that much more than you.

Good luck!!
how did you first learn that these are trending? And how would you learn whether one of them becomes old-fashioned or not (since nearly everyday we have a new technological invention)

> how did you first learn that these are trending?

Hacker News, Reddit, GitHub, coworkers/peers, ...

> And how would you learn whether one of them becomes old-fashioned or not (since nearly everyday we have a new technological invention)

I wouldn't worry about that too much.

Try Hacker News. I usually check it several times a day.

I agree with the student answer though -- it really boils down to coding a lot in your free time and being genuinely excited about keeping up with recent trends in front-end/back-end/ML/systems/PL/security/design/theory/whatever.

Same, getting interviews as a freshman is already an insane accomplishment. I'm declared CS second year with a 4.0, haven't gotten any interviews at any company, it seems like most companies only want juniors. I thought it's because my side projects are weak and GPA is meaningless without solid side-projects or previous internships, but it sounds like OP doesn't have side projects or previous internships, so now I'm all confused...

Hi, OP here. You're right I don't really have any side projects (besides stuff I've done in 61a/61b), however, I'm quite involved on campus. So far I've gotten an interview with Intuit bc I did an externship for them over winter and they offered all the externs 'free' interviews. All the other interviews I've had have been through Angel list https://angel.co/ or through messaging people on Linkedin (sometimes aggressively). But as far as 'big' companies (fortune 500), I haven't had many interviews.
Oh wow. I'm guessing the 'externship' probably helped a lot in getting interviews though right? How did you get that opportunity? Is an externship just a really short internship?

Yeah hhaha just having the word 'Intuit' on my resume was definitely a big help. To actually get the externship, all I had to do was sign up on Cal's externship portal... I don't even think they rejected anyone from the program haha. But now I think I get an interview with Intuit every year. The program itself was only a three day visit to Intuit where we did a UX redesign (with no code) on the Mint App. Really fun, would definitely recommend.

Don't forget about programs designed specifically for freshmen/sophomores (Google EP, Explore Microsoft, Facebook U, etc.).

What the second anon said above is true: most companies are (understandably) more inclined to hire juniors over equally qualified freshmen/sophomores. Don't take it personally! Just keep up the good work and keep applying! (intern.supply is a cool resource for finding more things to apply to.)

Serious question: how do you get interviews for internships if you don't have experience before college? I've taken 61a, 61b, and 70, and am taking 170 and 188 right now. I have some non-trivial side projects and have a pretty good GPA. I've also been applying for (many) internships since September, and haven't gotten a single interview. I'm not sure what else to do at this point.

history.content:
Hi, I'm a Freshman in CS with no prior CS experience. So far, this hasn't inhibited my abilities to perform in an academic context; however, I've found that I feel quite disadvantaged with regards to 'being up to speed' in the industry. So far all of the interviews I've had for companies have played out as follows: I do relatively well (or at least passable) on the technical coding questions, but finish red faced as I fail to amount to any competency in even a casual conversation about a project. Words like 'stack', 'API', 'Framework', etc are extremely foreign to me (having no desire to do CS until entering Berkeley). Therefore, I was hoping someone could provide advice for becoming acquainted with such industry terminology (and I mean fully grasp, not just 'know'). Thank you.

tl:dr -- What are some good resources (websites/ Reddit channels/ books/ etc) for learning the industry lingo we don't learn in class?
history.subject: General CS Advice
